point.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a single fact, idea, or opinion that is part of an argument or discussion
point.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: She made some extremely good points.
There are three important points we must bear in mind.
This brings me to my next point.
I agree with John’s point about keeping the costs down.
point.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the purpose or aim of something
point.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: I suppose we could save one or two of the trees, but what’s the point?
We’re going to lose anyway, so I can’t see the point of playing.
I didn’t see the point in moving to London.
What’s the point of this meeting anyway?
The whole point of this legislation is to protect children.
point.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The accident happened at the point where the A15 joins the M1.
No cars are allowed beyond this point.
Cairo is a convenient departure point for tours.
Dover is a point of entry into Britain.
point.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: an exact moment, time, or stage in the development of something
point.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: I had reached a point in my career where I needed to decide which way to go.
She had got to the point where she felt that she could not take any more.
Their win over old rivals Manchester United was the high point (=best part) in their season.
Sales reached a low point in 1996.
We will take last week’s riots as a starting point for our discussion.
At one point, I thought he was going to burst into tears.
Maybe at this point we should move onto some of the practical experiments.
At that point, I was still living at home and had no job.
You will probably sell the car at some point in the future.
It is impossible to give a definite answer at this point in time.
Some children are bullied to the point of suicide  (=until they reach this stage).
point.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a particular quality or feature that something or someone has
point.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: The low price is one of its main selling points (=features that will help to sell it).
Driving was not one of Baxter’s strong points.
One of the club’s plus points is that it is central.
There were some weak points in his argument.
Sometimes she had to remind herself of his good points.
They would spend hours discussing the finer points (=small details about qualities and features) of various cars.
point.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: one of the marks or numbers that shows your score in a game or sport
point.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: He is three points behind the leader.
Leeds United are now six points clear at the top of the table.
She had to win this point.
You get three points for a win and one point for a draw.
You lose a point if you do not complete the puzzle on time.
The fight went the full fifteen rounds, and in the end the American won on points.
point.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: the sharp point of a spear
point.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: a sign (.) used to separate a whole number from any decimals that follow it
point.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a mark or measure on a scale
point.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: The stock market has fallen by over 200 points in the last week.
point.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: a very small spot of light or colour
point.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: The stars shone like points of light in the sky.
point.translation[0].definitions[10].def: one of the marks on a compass that shows direction
point.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: Soldiers were advancing on us from all points of the compass.
point.translation[0].definitions[11].def: a long thin piece of land that stretches out into the sea
point.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: We sailed round the point into a small, sheltered bay.
point.translation[0].definitions[12].def: a piece of plastic with holes in it which is attached to a wall and to which electrical equipment can be connected
point.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: a single fact, idea, or opinion that is part of an argument or discussion
point.translation[0].note_box[0].section: I think that’s a very good point.

That’s an important point to bear in mind.
He’s making a joke but there is a serious point there as well.
She raised a number of valid points.
I’d like to make one further general point.
Kevin Phillips made a similar point in his 1993 book, ‘Boiling Point’.
Finally, I will summarise the main points of this chapter.
There is one final point I would like to make.
He makes the point that predicting behaviour is not easy.
I think we got our point across.
I was going to raise that point.
A simple example will illustrate the point.
He was determined to prove his point.
I’m sorry, I don’t understand your point.
OK, I take your point. But it’s not that easy.
I don’t wish to labour the point, but why didn’t you just tell me?
Could you clarify a couple of points for me?
All right, point taken – I should have asked you first.
I’m afraid I don’t understand the finer points of the game.
point.translation[0].note_box[1].section: The point is that going by bus would be a lot cheaper.
That’s the point. She didn’t tell us what was going on.
We'd earn a lot of money, but that's not the point.

When did she leave, and, more to the point, why?
I haven't got much time so let's get straight to the point.
He didn’t get the point at first.
I don't know why but Mel always seems to miss the point.
point.translation[0].note_box[2].heading: – Meaning 5: an exact moment, time, or stage in the development of something
point.translation[0].note_box[2].section: Some couples reach a point where divorce is the only solution.
You get to the point where ordinary things like climbing stairs are difficult.
The day of the accident marked a turning point in Kenny’s life.
Winning the World Championship was the high point of my career.
She helped me when I was at a low point in my life.
The following recipes are a good starting point for making your own bread.

The tensions within the country have reached crisis point.
Our resources are stretched to breaking point.
The hospital was full to bursting point.

At one point I was thinking of studying physics.
Over half the population suffers from back pain at some point in their lives.
I’m not prepared at this point to make any decision.
It would be wrong to comment at this point in time.
British industry was driven to the point of collapse.
There comes a point where you have to accept defeat.
point.translation[0].note_box[3].heading: – Meaning 6: a particular quality or feature that something or someone has
point.translation[0].note_box[3].section: Every system has its good points and its drawbacks.
What would you say are Natalie’s bad points?
Mathematics was never my strong point.
Be honest about assessing your weak points.
The airline’s outstanding safety record is a major plus point.
Underfloor heating has a lot of positive points.
A few negative points should be mentioned.
The house's main selling point is its beautiful garden.
I'm afraid I'm not interested in the finer points of cars.
point.translation[0].note_box[4].heading: – Meaning 7: one of the marks or numbers that shows your score in a game or sport
point.translation[0].note_box[4].section: The Kiwis scored 206 points in their three matches.
I didn't win a single point in my first few games.
Our aim is to get as many points as possible.
If he’s got the answer wrong, he loses 250 points.
I was awarded 17 points out of 20.
We only lost by two points.
He was knocked down twice, before losing on points.
The teams finished level on points.
point.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to show something to someone by holding up one of your fingers or a thin object towards it
point.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: She pointed in the direction of the car park.
He stood up and pointed his finger at me.
I could see him pointing at me and telling the other guests what I had said.
She was pointing to a small boat that was approaching the shore.
The driver pointed with his whip.
point.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to hold something so that it is aimed towards a person or thing
point.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: He stood up and pointed his gun at the prisoner.
She produced a camera and pointed it at me.
point.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to face or be aimed in a particular direction
point.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: There were flashlights all around us, pointing in all directions.
There were TV cameras pointing at us.
The hands of the clock pointed to a quarter past one.
We found footprints pointing towards the back door.
point.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to show someone which direction they should go in
point.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: She pointed me towards an armchair.
Could you point me in the direction of the bathroom, please?
point.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to suggest what someone should do
point.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: My teachers were all pointing me towards university.
A financial adviser should be able to point you in the right direction.
point.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to suggest that something is true
point.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: Everything seemed to point in one direction.
All the evidence pointed towards Blake as the murderer.
Everything points to her having died from a drugs overdose.
point.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: to put new cement between the bricks of a wall
point.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a single idea, opinion, or fact, especially one that is part of a plan, argument, or discussion
point.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: I agree with your point about the importance of safety.
He made the point that economic growth would create the wealth necessary to protect the environment.
point.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Gas prices have reached their highest point so far this year.
The president’s approval rating has hit its lowest point.
point.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: the main idea in something that is said or done which gives meaning to all of it
point.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The point is that staff are not allowed to smoke in the building.
Have I completely missed the point (=failed to understand the main meaning of something)?
point.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: one of a series of parts into which a meeting, plan etc is divided
point.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: What’s the first point on the agenda?
The corporation announced a five-point plan for overhauling its businesses.
point.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: a unit of measure used in INDEXES (=series of figures giving the general level of financial markets, economic activity etc)
point.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: The Financial Times 30 Share Index closed up 11 points at 1659.5.
point.translation[2].definitions[5].exam: Your luggage will be searched at thepoint of departure.
Visas cannot be issued at the entry points along the border.
point.translation[2].definitions[6].defi: an exact moment, time, or stage in the development or progress of something
point.translation[2].definitions[6].exam: It is too early to tell whether last month’s increase marks a turning point (=a time when a situation changes) for the company.
The economy seems to be moving to the point of no return (=the point where it becomes so bad it cannot recover).
point.translation[2].definitions[7].defi: a unit used to measure how good someone or something is or how suitable they are for something
point.translation[2].definitions[7].exam: The details you give are assessed according to a points system.
point.translation[2].definitions[8].defi: a particular quality or feature that something or someone has
point.translation[2].definitions[8].exam: Finance has never been his strong point.
Every system has its good points and its drawbacks.
point.translation[2].definitions[9].defi: a sign (.) used to separate a whole number from any DECIMALs that follow it
point.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: To minimise his sentence, he pointed the finger at people he had dealt with.
point.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to show how something could change or develop successfully
point.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The article summarises the current law and points the way forward.
